signals.structural_force: Chapter 11 filings at 10-year high; PE-backed companies 30% of all filings. Minsky moment in PE roll-ups is materializing.
signals.headline: Commercial Chapter 11 filings rose ~20% YoY; PE-backed firms 30% of all US bankruptcies in 2024-2025
signals.detail: Total US bankruptcy filings increased 11% in 2025. Commercial Chapter 11 filings rose nearly 20% YoY, with companies over $100M in assets filing up 44%. PE-backed companies now account for 30% of filings, up 15% from prior year. Distress is projected to remain elevated through 2026.
signals.opportunity_hypothesis: Distressed PE roll-up portfolios in professional services (accounting, staffing, healthcare services) will produce forced asset sales. An agentic-first acquirer can buy client books at 0.3-0.5x revenue vs. historical 1.5-2.5x, then serve those clients at 10x lower cost structure.
raw_data_points: Chapter 11 filings at 10-year high (2025)
PE-backed firms = 30% of all US bankruptcy filings (2024)
Large company filings ($100M+ assets) up 44% YoY mid-2025
PE firms struggling to exit via IPO or sale
Distress projected elevated through 2026
barriers_noted: Acquiring distressed assets requires deal flow and legal expertise

signals.structural_force: LLM inference costs dropped 280x in 18 months for equivalent performance. API price war in progress. Application-layer economics fundamentally changed.
signals.headline: AI inference prices fell 9x-900x annually depending on tier (2023-2025); GPT-4-equivalent performance now 40x cheaper per year
signals.detail: Inference costs dropped over 280-fold in 18 months for comparable performance. Prices fell 9x annually for basic models to 900x for top-tier. Cloud providers in active price war. This is the infrastructure overhang that makes application-layer businesses viable at unit economics that were impossible 18 months ago.
signals.opportunity_hypothesis: Every cognitive service business that was marginally viable at 2024 inference costs is now deeply viable. The application layer is where value creation shifts. Businesses consuming cheap inference to deliver real-economy services capture the surplus.
raw_data_points: 280x cost reduction in 18 months for equivalent performance
40x/year price decline for GPT-4-level science reasoning
Active API price war among providers (OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, open-source)
95% of generative AI pilots failed to generate business impact (Bessemer)
Hybrid/usage-based pricing models surging, seat-based declining

signals.structural_force: 75% of CPAs approaching retirement + enrollment in accounting programs declining. AI-powered tax/bookkeeping can serve the 70% of small businesses that cannot afford a CPA.
signals.headline: 3 in 4 CPAs approaching retirement; 70% of small businesses don't use a CPA due to cost; AI accounting market growing 44-46% CAGR
signals.detail: The CPA shortage is structural and worsening: 75% approaching retirement, declining enrollment. Meanwhile, 70% of US small businesses (roughly 23M businesses) handle their own finances because CPAs cost $200-500/hr. AI accounting market reached $7.5B in 2025, growing 44-46% CAGR to $50-68B by 2030-31. Deduction raised $2.8M targeting consumers paying $1K-$10K for CPA services.
signals.opportunity_hypothesis: Build AI-first accounting/tax service targeting the 23M US small businesses that can't afford a CPA. At $50-200/month (vs. $2K-10K/yr for CPA), Jevons expansion unlocks 3-5x TAM. The CPA shortage means incumbents can't grow to meet demand even if they wanted to.
raw_data_points: 75% of CPAs approaching retirement
64% of accounting professionals have received no AI training
70% of US small businesses don't use a CPA
AI in accounting market: $7.5B (2025) -> $50-68B (2030-31)
Deduction raised $2.8M targeting $1K-$10K CPA customers
95% of accounting professionals believe AI central to workflow within 5 years
barriers_noted: CPA licensing requirements for certain services

signals.structural_force: AI agent market growing 46% CAGR to $52.6B by 2030. Gartner predicts 40% of enterprise apps will have AI agents by end 2026 (up from <5% in 2025). New business category emerging.
signals.headline: AI agent market: $7.8B (2025) -> $52.6B (2030) at 46% CAGR; Gartner: 40% enterprise apps will embed agents by end 2026
signals.detail: The agentic AI category is the fastest-growing segment in enterprise software. Vertical AI investment tripled in 2025 to $3.5B. Gartner predicts 8x growth in enterprise agent adoption in just one year (5% to 40%). This creates massive demand for agent infrastructure, orchestration, and industry-specific agent development.
signals.opportunity_hypothesis: Build vertical AI agent solutions for specific industries (insurance, healthcare admin, legal). The 'Service-as-Software' model replaces SaaS: instead of selling tools to professionals, sell the outcome directly. First movers in regulated verticals build compliance moats.
raw_data_points: AI agent market: $7.8B (2025) at 46% CAGR
Vertical AI investment tripled to $3.5B in 2025
Gartner: 40% enterprise apps with agents by end 2026 (from <5%)
Service-as-Software replacing SaaS paradigm
ProCap Financial becoming first publicly traded agentic finance firm (Feb 2026)
barriers_noted: Commodity risk if agents become interchangeable

signals.source_name: National Law Review / Y Combinator RFS
signals.structural_force: YC explicitly calling for AI-first law firms to compete with incumbents. Legal tech market doubling. AI-native obelisk model replacing traditional pyramid staffing. First M&A of AI-first legal firms by traditional firms expected 2026.
signals.headline: Y Combinator calls for AI-staffed law firms; legal AI market to double in 2026; consolidation beginning among legal AI vendors
signals.detail: YC's 2025 RFS explicitly urged founders to 'start your own law firm, staff it with AI agents.' Legal tech market growing from $29.8B (2025) to $65.5B (2034). AI-native firms are reshaping from pyramid to obelisk model (fewer junior staff, new pricing away from billable hours). Vendor consolidation expected in 2026 as overlapping capabilities shake out. Major law firm or ALSP expected to acquire an AI-first firm.
signals.opportunity_hypothesis: Build an AI-first legal services firm targeting SMBs and mid-market companies currently paying $300-600/hr. Focus on high-volume, routine-cognitive legal work (contract review, compliance, entity formation, trademark). Deliver at 80% lower cost. Judgment-premium layer: human attorneys handle complex strategy at premium rates.
raw_data_points: Y Combinator RFS 2025: 'start your own law firm, staff it with AI agents'
Legal tech market: $29.8B (2025) -> $65.5B (2034) at 9.14% CAGR
AI-native 'obelisk model' replacing traditional pyramid
Vendor consolidation expected 2026
Major firm/ALSP acquisition of AI-first firm expected 2026
No large-scale AI job displacement in legal yet — disruption at margins

signals.structural_force: Nursing shortage of 200K-500K by 2025-2030. Median RN age 52. Nearly 1M RNs over 50. Only 2.9 workers per senior projected (down from 4). AI can give nurses 20% more patient care time.
signals.headline: US nursing shortfall projected 200K-500K by 2025-2030; median RN age 52; 1M RNs over age 50; AI could save $150B/yr in healthcare
signals.detail: HRSA projects 500K+ RN shortfall by 2030. Median RN age is 52, with 20%+ planning retirement within 5 years. Workers-per-senior ratio dropping from 4 to 2.9. Deloitte estimates GenAI could give nurses 20% more patient care time. Healthcare AI could save $150B/yr. This is the highest-urgency demographic gap in the US economy.
signals.opportunity_hypothesis: Build AI clinical assistant that handles documentation, triage, scheduling, and follow-up for nursing teams. Each AI system effectively adds 20% capacity per nurse. At 3M+ RNs in the US, that's equivalent to 600K additional nurses worth of capacity. Target hospital systems and home health agencies facing acute shortages.
raw_data_points: HRSA: 500K+ RN shortfall by 2030
Median RN age: 52
Nearly 1M RNs over age 50
Workers-per-senior ratio: 4 -> 2.9 projected
73% of those 65+ will need increased healthcare by 2029
Deloitte: GenAI gives nurses 20% more patient care time
Healthcare AI: $150B/yr potential savings
Insurance industry losing 400K workers through attrition by 2026

signals.structural_force: 47 states introduced 250+ AI healthcare bills in 2025; 33 signed into law. Regulation fragmenting by use case. Compliance complexity creates first-mover moat for regulated AI healthcare services.
signals.headline: 47 states introduced 250+ AI healthcare bills in 2025; 33 laws enacted. Patchwork regulation creates compliance moat.
signals.detail: The regulatory landscape for AI in healthcare is fragmenting rapidly. States are moving from broad governance to use-case-specific regulation (payor algorithms, mental health chatbots, clinical decision support). Utah enacted first AI mental health tool law (March 2025). 60 bills specifically targeting AI in insurance. This patchwork creates massive compliance burden that benefits first movers who navigate it.
signals.opportunity_hypothesis: The regulatory fragmentation IS the moat. Build an AI healthcare service that achieves compliance across multiple states first. The compliance cost ($500K-1M setup) and time (12-18 months) blocks fast followers. Once compliant, serve the entire national market with competitors locked out by the same barriers you overcame.
raw_data_points: 47 states introduced 250+ AI healthcare bills (2025)
33 laws enacted across 21 states
Utah: first AI mental health tool law (March 2025)
60 bills targeting AI in insurance specifically
Arizona, Maryland, Nebraska, Texas: enacted insurer AI laws
Model law on third-party AI oversight anticipated 2026
barriers_noted: Evolving regulatory landscape requires ongoing monitoring

signals.structural_force: Insurance industry losing 400K workers through attrition by 2026. 91% of insurers expected to adopt AI. Claims processing is 70%+ routine cognitive work (Polanyi classification). Perfect Baumol cure candidate.
signals.headline: Insurance industry losing 400K workers by 2026; 91% of insurers adopting AI; claims processing is prime automation target
signals.detail: BLS projects 400K worker attrition in insurance by 2026. Claims processing is largely routine cognitive work (data extraction, form processing, damage assessment). AI-in-insurance market growing from $7.7B (2024) to $35.8B (2029). Avallon, Sprout.ai, Tractable showing strong traction. The demographic gap + routine-cognitive work classification = highest-readiness Baumol cure candidate.
signals.opportunity_hypothesis: Build AI claims processing service targeting Third-Party Administrators and small-to-mid insurers who can't build in-house. Focus on the LATAM insurance market (weak incumbents, growing market, Spanish-language advantage). Service-as-Software model: charge per claim processed, not per seat.
raw_data_points: 400K insurance workers lost through attrition by 2026 (BLS)
91% of insurers expected to adopt AI by 2026
Avallon: 10x revenue growth during YC S25
Allianz launched first agentic AI for claims (Nov 2025)
Model law for third-party AI oversight anticipated 2026
barriers_noted: Compliance moat potential is very high

signals.structural_force: LATAM IT services market growing from $11.8B to $47.9B (2025-2031, 26% CAGR). 45% of US companies increasing LATAM hiring. Mexico surpassing Brazil in AI/fintech volume. LATAM services exports up 27%.
signals.headline: LATAM AI/IT market: $11.8B -> $47.9B (26% CAGR); 45% of US companies increasing LATAM hiring; Mexico leads in AI/fintech
signals.detail: Latin America's AI IT market is scaling from $11.8B (2025) to $47.9B by 2031. IT outsourcing revenue at $70.8B (2024), on track for $126.3B by 2030. 45% of US companies plan to increase LATAM hiring. Mexico surpassed Brazil in volume driven by AI, fintech, nearshoring. Brazil and Mexico account for 95% of AI patents in region. Services exports up 27% YoY.
signals.opportunity_hypothesis: Build AI-powered professional services targeting US companies nearshoring to LATAM. Offer bilingual (English/Spanish) AI-first compliance, HR, and finance services for companies operating across US-LATAM. Founders' Argentina background + bilingual capability is direct competitive advantage.
raw_data_points: LATAM AI IT market: $11.8B (2025) -> $47.9B (2031), 26% CAGR
45% of US companies increasing LATAM hiring (2025)
Mexico surpassed Brazil in AI/fintech volume
Brazil + Mexico = 95% of LATAM AI patents
LATAM services exports up 27% YoY
barriers_noted: Currency volatility in some LATAM markets

signals.structural_force: RegTech market $18.6B (2025) growing to $85-115B by 2035. AI-specific RegTech growing 36-40% CAGR. Cloud-based deployment 75% share. Multi-state/multi-jurisdiction compliance is the fastest-growing pain point.
signals.headline: RegTech market: $18.6B (2025) -> $85-115B (2035); AI-powered RegTech growing 36-40% CAGR
signals.detail: The compliance burden is accelerating faster than companies can hire compliance officers. AI-in-RegTech forecast to reach $3.3B by 2026 at 36% CAGR. The fragmentation of AI regulation across states and countries creates a Jevons expansion opportunity: companies that previously couldn't afford compliance teams can now afford AI compliance. Cloud-based deployment dominates at 75%. Banking/financial services = 50% of market.
signals.opportunity_hypothesis: Build AI compliance service targeting SMBs expanding across jurisdictions. Focus on the intersection of AI regulation + industry-specific regulation (healthcare AI compliance, fintech AI compliance). The regulatory fragmentation makes this a natural moat — solving multi-jurisdiction compliance is expensive to replicate.
raw_data_points: RegTech market: $18.6B (2025)
AI in RegTech: $3.3B by 2026, 36% CAGR
Cloud-based deployment: 75% share
Banking/financial services: 50% of RegTech market
North America: 41% market share
Asia-Pacific: fastest growth at 38% CAGR

signals.structural_force: 400K+ skilled trade jobs unfilled, projected 2M by 2033. 41% of construction workforce retiring by 2031. Electrician jobs growing 9%. HVAC shortage 225K. These are tacit-manual jobs (Polanyi) — AI can't replace them but CAN augment dispatch, scheduling, customer management.
signals.headline: 400K+ skilled trade jobs unfilled in US; projected 2M by 2033; 41% of construction workforce retiring by 2031
signals.detail: The skilled trades shortage is the largest Polanyi-classified labor gap in the US. Electrician openings: 81K/yr projected. HVAC shortage: 225K by 2025. Construction: 41% retiring by 2031. These are tacit-manual jobs that AI cannot replace (physical dexterity + spatial reasoning). But back-office, dispatch, scheduling, customer acquisition, and business management are all routine-cognitive — ripe for AI. Data center construction demand is amplifying the shortage.
signals.opportunity_hypothesis: Build an AI-powered business operations platform for skilled trades (HVAC, plumbing, electrical). Handle scheduling, dispatch, customer communication, invoicing, and lead management. The tradespeople focus on the tacit-manual work (their premium rises per Baumol Premium). The platform captures the routine-cognitive work at 10x lower cost.
raw_data_points: 400K+ skilled trade jobs unfilled (BLS)
Projected 2M unfilled by 2033
41% of construction workforce retiring by 2031
Electrician: 9% employment growth, 81K openings/yr
HVAC shortage: 225K by 2025
Data center construction amplifying demand
Skilled trades now out-earning college graduates

signals.structural_force: Healthcare CPI has exceeded headline CPI for decades (4.5% vs 2.5%). AI can address administrative burden (30%+ of healthcare costs). Stored Baumol energy in healthcare = largest cure opportunity in the US economy.
signals.headline: Healthcare CPI +4.5%/yr vs headline +2.5%/yr for decades = massive stored Baumol energy. Administrative costs 30%+ of total. AI poised to cure the disease.
signals.detail: Healthcare has the longest-running and largest Baumol cost disease in the US economy. Administrative costs account for 30%+ of the $4.3T US healthcare spend ($1.3T in admin alone). AI can automate medical coding, prior authorization, claims processing, documentation, and scheduling. The Jevons expansion: at 10x lower admin cost, smaller clinics and practices that currently operate with minimal admin support could provide more structured, compliant operations.
signals.opportunity_hypothesis: Build AI healthcare administration service targeting independent practices and small hospital networks. Automate medical coding, prior auth, claims, and documentation. At current admin costs of $20-40 per claim, AI can process at $2-5. The 600K+ independent physician practices in the US are massively underserved.
raw_data_points: US healthcare spend: $4.3T
Administrative costs: 30%+ ($1.3T+)
Healthcare CPI: 4.5%/yr vs 2.5% headline for 20+ years
600K+ independent physician practices in US
Medical coding error rate: 10-30% (human)
Prior authorization: avg 13 hours/week per physician office

signals.structural_force: 79% of CFOs report 25%+ of finance work handled by agentic AI. ProCap Financial becoming first publicly traded agentic finance firm (Feb 2026). 78% of CFOs still experimenting. Massive deployment gap = opportunity window.
signals.headline: 79% of CFOs: 25%+ of finance work now handled by agentic AI; first publicly traded agentic finance firm emerging (Feb 2026)
signals.detail: The finance function is rapidly shifting to agentic AI. 79% of CFOs say 25%+ of accounting/finance workload handled by AI, but 78% say they're still experimenting. ProCap Financial is becoming the first publicly traded agentic finance firm via acquisition of CFO Silvia, Inc. (Feb 2026). The gap between adoption and confidence creates a hybrid model opportunity.
signals.opportunity_hypothesis: Build an AI-first fractional CFO service targeting businesses with $500K-$20M revenue. AI handles bookkeeping, forecasting, tax prep, and reporting. Human CFO handles strategy and judgment. Price at $500-2000/month vs. $5K-15K/month for traditional fractional CFO. Jevons expansion: serve the 80% of small businesses that can't afford any CFO services.
raw_data_points: 79% of CFOs: 25%+ finance work via agentic AI
28% of CFOs: 50%+ handled by agentic AI
78% of CFOs still in experimentation phase
ProCap Financial: first publicly traded agentic finance firm (Feb 2026)
66% of mid-market CFOs say human oversight extremely/very critical

signals.structural_force: AI tutoring market: $3.5B (2025) -> $6.5B (2030). Education CPI has exceeded headline for 20+ years. 50M+ US K-12 students; private tutoring historically accessible only to top 10-20% income bracket. At 10x lower cost, Jevons expansion could 5x the market.
signals.headline: AI tutoring: $3.5B -> $6.5B by 2030. Education Baumol cure: private tutoring historically only for wealthy 10-20%, AI could serve 80%+
signals.detail: Education has the second-largest Baumol cost disease after healthcare. Private tutoring costs $40-100/hr, accessible primarily to affluent families. AI tutoring at $5-15/hr equivalent unlocks the 80% of families priced out. Mobile-first platforms reaching underserved areas. Microsoft, Carnegie Learning investing heavily. The ISA (income-sharing) and subscription models lowering barriers further.
signals.opportunity_hypothesis: Build AI tutoring platform targeting the 80% of families that can't afford private tutors. Focus on high-stakes subjects (SAT prep, math, science) where outcomes are measurable. Price at $20-50/month vs. $200-500/month for human tutors. LATAM expansion natural: massive underserved education market, Spanish language.
raw_data_points: AI tutoring market: $3.5B (2025) -> $6.5B (2030)
Private tutoring: $40-100/hr currently
Only 10-20% of families can afford regular private tutoring
50M+ US K-12 students
Mobile-first platforms reaching underserved Tier 2-3 cities

signals.structural_force: Insurance claims automation was attempted multiple times in 2010s (Lemonade, Hippo, etc.) with mixed results due to high error rates and customer trust issues. Current AI capabilities (multimodal, vision, NLU) make the unit economics work. Avallon 10x'd revenue in YC.
signals.headline: Insurance claims automation revived: Avallon 10x'd revenue at YC S25; Allianz launched agentic claims AI; multimodal AI solves prior accuracy barriers
signals.detail: Insurance claims automation was a repeatedly attempted business model that stumbled on accuracy, trust, and cost. Previous attempts required large teams for exception handling. Current multimodal AI (vision for damage assessment, NLU for document processing) achieves accuracy levels that tip unit economics. Avallon's 10x revenue growth at YC validates the revival thesis. Allianz (established insurer) launching agentic claims AI confirms institutional readiness.
raw_data_points: Avallon: 10x revenue growth during YC S25, $4.6M raised
Allianz: first agentic claims AI launched (Nov 2025)
Tractable: computer vision for vehicle/property damage
Lemonade's original 2016 thesis was premature — AI accuracy wasn't there
barriers_noted: Trust barrier being overcome by incumbent adoption (Allianz)

signals.structural_force: Service-as-Software replacing SaaS. AI automation micro-agencies launching at $2K-$5K, scaling to $5K-$50K/month. Middleware and data infrastructure ('unsexy' infra) identified as most durable model. 90-99% of AI startups expected to die — creating distressed talent and IP acquisition opportunities.
signals.headline: Service-as-Software paradigm replacing SaaS; 90-99% AI startup mortality creating talent/IP acquisition window; middleware as durable model
signals.detail: The AI startup shakeout is creating a P2-like cascade within the AI industry itself. 90-99% of AI startups projected to die by end 2026. Surviving models: Service-as-Software (sell outcomes, not tools), middleware/data infrastructure, and vertical-specific agents. The dying startups leave behind trained talent, fine-tuned models, and customer relationships — acquirable at distressed prices.
signals.opportunity_hypothesis: Acqui-hire from dying AI startups. Buy fine-tuned models, domain datasets, and talent at distressed prices. Combine with a revenue-generating Service-as-Software model in a specific vertical. The AI startup shakeout is a version of the PE roll-up distress — but in AI itself.
raw_data_points: 90-99% of AI startups projected to die by end 2026
AI micro-agencies: $2K-5K launch cost, $5K-50K/month revenue potential
95% of GenAI pilots failed to produce business impact
Service-as-Software replacing SaaS paradigm
Middleware/data infra identified as most durable business model
barriers_noted: Finding quality targets among the noise

signals.structural_force: FINRA 2026 report puts AI governance under scrutiny. Financial services firms deploying AI without adequate governance. No explicit AI-specific regulation yet but existing compliance obligations still apply. First-mover compliance companies will set the standard.
signals.headline: FINRA 2026: AI adoption outpacing governance in financial services; compliance gap creates regtech opportunity
signals.detail: FINRA's 2026 Regulatory Oversight Report flags that AI adoption in financial services is racing ahead of governance frameworks. Firms deploying AI without adequate controls for communications, supervision, and documentation. No explicit AI-specific regulation yet, but firms remain fully accountable. This creates a window for compliance-first AI service providers to become the default standard before regulation codifies.
raw_data_points: FINRA 2026 report: AI governance under scrutiny
Adoption racing ahead of controls
No explicit AI regulation yet — existing rules apply
Financial services: 50% of RegTech market

signals.structural_force: AI reshaping accounting by handling the 'boring stuff' — data entry, reconciliation, standard tax prep. 60%+ of adoption driven by automation features. 40% of SMEs cite cost and complexity as barriers. The cost barrier IS the Jevons expansion signal.
signals.headline: AI levels playing field for small business accounting; 60%+ adoption driven by automation; 40% of SMEs blocked by cost/complexity
signals.detail: Stanford GSB research shows AI is handling routine accounting work ('the boring stuff'), freeing accountants for advisory. 60%+ of small business software adoption is driven by automation features. But 40% of SMEs still cite cost and complexity as barriers. This 40% represents the Jevons expansion market — businesses that WANT financial management but can't overcome the friction.
raw_data_points: 60%+ of adoption driven by automation features
40% of SMEs blocked by cost/complexity
45% cite learning curve as barrier
SMBs adopting AI at 43% growth rate (2024-2029)

signals.structural_force: Skilled trades back-office costs consume 20-30% of revenue but tradespeople hate admin work. AI dispatch/scheduling/invoicing can free 10-15 hours/week per tradesperson. At 2M+ trade businesses in the US, the back-office market alone is $20B+.
signals.headline: Skilled trades back-office reinvention: AI can free 10-15 hrs/week per tradesperson; 2M+ trade businesses in US
signals.detail: Back-office work is the primary productivity bottleneck for skilled trades businesses. Tradespeople spend 20-30% of their time on scheduling, dispatch, invoicing, and customer communication — all routine-cognitive work. AI can automate most of this, freeing physical workers to focus on billable tacit-manual work. The premium for the human work rises as supply tightens.

10-15 hours/week recoverable with AI back-office
2M+ trade businesses in US
Avg trade business: $250K-$2M revenue
Back-office market: $20B+ estimated

signals.source_name: Wilson Sonsini / Manatt / State legislation trackers
signals.structural_force: Patchwork AI regulation across 47+ states and EU AI Act creating compliance maze. Companies operating across jurisdictions face exponentially growing compliance burden. This is a structural tailwind for compliance-as-a-service businesses.
signals.headline: AI regulatory fragmentation: 47 states, EU AI Act, sector-specific rules creating compliance maze; structural tailwind for compliance services
signals.detail: The AI regulatory landscape is fragmenting faster than any prior technology regulation cycle. 47 states with AI bills, EU AI Act fully effective, sector-specific rules multiplying. Companies face a compliance matrix (state x sector x use-case). This is Jevons expansion for compliance services: previously, only large enterprises needed compliance teams. Now every company using AI needs compliance — at any size.

EU AI Act fully effective
Sector-specific AI rules in healthcare, insurance, financial services
Model law for AI third-party oversight expected 2026
FINRA governance report flagging compliance gaps

signals.structural_force: Refinancing wall + AI margin compression creating double squeeze. 2020-2021 low-rate debt maturing 2025-2027. PE funds unable to exit. Distressed assets becoming available at depressed multiples. This is T15 (Minsky Extended) materializing.
signals.headline: 2020-2021 debt cohort refinancing at higher rates while AI compresses margins — double squeeze forcing distressed sales
signals.detail: The PE refinancing wall is colliding with AI-driven margin compression. Companies that borrowed at 3-4% in 2020-2021 now face refinancing at 7-9%. Simultaneously, AI entrants are compressing pricing in professional services, staffing, and mid-market services. PE firms can't exit via IPO (narrow window) or sale (compressed multiples). Result: forced exits, asset sales, and liquidation of client books at distressed prices.
raw_data_points: 2020-2021 borrowing cohort: $1T+ in debt maturing 2025-2027
Current refinancing rates: 7-9% vs original 3-4%
PE-backed bankruptcies: 30% of all filings
IPO window narrow for traditional services businesses
K-shaped economy straining lower/middle income spending
barriers_noted: Deal flow access requires industry connections

signals.structural_force: AI infrastructure overbuild becoming visible: data centers half-empty, energy bills unpaid, startups folding. The Perez Installation-to-Deployment transition is underway. Post-crash infrastructure becomes cheap inputs for deployment-phase businesses.
signals.headline: AI infrastructure overbuild visible: half-empty data centers, unpaid energy bills, startup failures. Perez turning point approaching.
signals.detail: The AI bubble dynamics are following the classic Perez Installation-to-Deployment pattern. Massive GPU/datacenter capex created overcapacity. AI startup failure rate accelerating. Unit economics upside-down for many apps. Infrastructure costs deflationary for end-users but inflationary at the frontier. The turning point creates cheap infrastructure for deployment-phase businesses that serve the real economy.
signals.opportunity_hypothesis: Build deployment-phase businesses that consume the overbuilt AI infrastructure at post-crash prices. Focus on real-economy transformation (healthcare, legal, trades, manufacturing) not digital-only applications. These are the businesses that thrive in Perez's Deployment Phase — crash-resilient, revenue-generating, physical-economy impact.
raw_data_points: Data centers reported half-empty
AI startup failure rate accelerating toward 90-99%
95% of GenAI pilots failed business impact
Unit economics inverted for many AI apps
Infrastructure costs deflationary for end users
barriers_noted: Timing uncertainty of the turning point

signals.structural_force: The accounting profession is at the Nash equilibrium tipping point. 95% believe AI will be central within 5 years but 64% have no training and 52% have no AI policies. The first firm to fully commit to AI-first model will trigger industry-wide defection.
signals.headline: Accounting profession: 95% believe AI central in 5 years; 64% no training; 52% no policies. Nash equilibrium about to break.
signals.detail: The accounting industry is in a classic T12 Nash equilibrium: everyone knows AI will transform the profession but no one wants to move first. 95% of professionals believe AI will be central to workflow within 5 years. But 64% have received no training. 52% of organizations lack AI policies. The first major firm that commits to AI-first and captures market share will trigger the cascade. Pre-defection = optimal entry window.
raw_data_points: 95% believe AI central to workflow within 5 years
64% have received no AI training
52% of firms lack AI policies
CPA shortage structural (75% retiring, enrollment declining)

signals.structural_force: AI micro-agency model emerging: small teams (1-3 people) offering AI-powered professional services (content, design, marketing, data analysis) at agency pricing but solo-operator costs. Coasean firm shrinkage in action — optimal firm size approaching 1-3 people for many services.
signals.headline: AI micro-agencies: 1-3 person teams delivering agency-level output at $5K-$50K/month; Coasean firm shrinkage in real-time
signals.detail: A new business category is emerging that doesn't fit traditional NAICS codes: the AI micro-agency. Solo operators or 2-3 person teams using AI to deliver what previously required 10-50 person agencies (marketing, content, design, data analysis, customer research). Launch costs: $2K-5K. Revenue: $5K-50K/month. This is T10 (Coase) in action — transaction costs for cognitive work collapsed so far that the optimal firm size approaches 1.
raw_data_points: AI micro-agencies launching at $2K-$5K investment
Revenue range: $5K-$50K/month
Replacing 10-50 person agency output with 1-3 people
AI content, design, marketing, data analysis as core services
barriers_noted: Low barriers to entry = high competition

signals.structural_force: Low-wage Baumol sectors (home care, social work, childcare, food service) have sparse competitive density for AI solutions. These sectors have lower margins than healthcare/legal but LARGER workforces and more severe demographic gaps. Underexplored by AI startups focused on high-margin sectors.
signals.headline: Low-wage Baumol sectors (home care, childcare, social work) underexplored by AI: large workforces, severe shortages, sparse AI competition
signals.detail: While AI startups focus on high-margin Baumol sectors (legal, healthcare, finance), low-wage Baumol sectors remain underserved. Home health aides: 4.6M workers, median age rising, chronic shortage. Childcare workers: declining workforce, rising costs, parents priced out. Social workers: growing caseloads, burnout, insufficient pipeline. These sectors can't afford $500/seat SaaS — but CAN afford $50/month AI tools. The Jevons expansion is enormous: millions of workers, each gaining 20-30% productivity.
signals.opportunity_hypothesis: Build ultra-low-cost AI operations platform for low-wage Baumol sectors. Target home health agencies, childcare centers, and social services organizations. Automate scheduling, documentation, compliance reporting, and communication. Price at $20-50/worker/month. Volume play: millions of potential users at low price point.
raw_data_points: Home health aides: 4.6M workers in US
Childcare: costs doubled in last decade, workforce declining
Social workers: burnout rates 40-60%
Median wages in these sectors: $15-$22/hr
AI competition density: very low (high-margin sectors attract all investment)
barriers_noted: Tech adoption lower in these sectors
